attributes.comment:
I am writing to argue against the current proposed fee increases as they relate to I-
600/I-600A petitions. Given the uncertain nature of the foreign adoption process,
many prospective adoptive parents are already in a position of having to complete
FBI fingerprinting 2-3 times and USCIS I-600/I-600A approval at least twice for the
adoption of the SAME child, because waiting times imposed by the foreign
country are increasing.

I am personally caught in this situation. My husband and I began paperwork in
early 2005 for the adoption of a child from China. We have already had to have our
FBI fingerprints redone. We also have recently submitted a second I-600
application, since our original approval expires soon. We will not be able to
complete travel to China to return with our daughter until later this year. Families
who have entered the China adoption program after us will have to wait even longer
between initial paperwork processing and completion of travel.

This means these families are already paying USCIS double the posted fee. If an
allowance can be made for paying one fee for the simultaneous adoption of
multiple children, then it seems like there should be only one fee paid for the
adoption of the same child.

I realize that the fact that the USCIS approval expires before many families are
able to complete their travel is on the one hand a separate issue from the
proposed fee increases. However, inasmuch as USCIS and Congressional
leadership appears unwilling to change the arbitrary nature of the length of approval
before expiry, then the proposed fee increase is a further burden for this set of
families who will be paying increased fee not once, but twice.

For most families, little if anything has changed from one I-600/I-600A submission
to the next (again, for the same adoption)--we are asked to submit additional
copies of the parents' birth certificates and marriage license, another "Copy of
Original Document" form, and an "updated" homestudy. In our case, the "update"
required another set of state police clearances and our social worker asking us
fewer than 10 questions that mainly related to criminal activity since we had had
no change in marital status, household residents, living arrangements, health, or
jobs/income. It hardly seems that even if the fee increase for the first submission
of I-600/I-600A is justifiable, subsequently forcing families in this situation to
submit essentially all of the same paperwork and pay the fee a second time
neither is efficient nor necessitates the same review process (i.e., USCIS should
face lower processing costs for renewals as opposed to initial applications).

USCIS appears to be looking to adoptive families, who are already stretched
financially to pay the host of fees required by the U.S. government, adoption
agencies, and the foreign government of their child's birth country, to subsidize
USCIS costs for other individuals. If USCIS is going to propose a restructured fee
system, then even if the I-600/I-600A fee is raised for the first submission to cover
expected processing costs, this is an opportunity to then introduce a significantly
reduced fee if families must file renewal due to delays in the same adoption.

If you have any questions or would like to ask me follow-up questions, please feel
free to contact me.
attributes.title: Comment Submitted By Stephanie M. Jozefowicz
